--- title: Types aliases: - types.html author: Marie-Hélène Burle --- ## Types systems ### Two main type systems in programming languages #### Static type-checking Type safety (catching errors of inadequate type) performed at compilation time. :::{.example} Examples: C, C++, Java, Fortran, Haskell. ::: #### Dynamic type-checking Type safety performed at runtime. :::{.example} Examples: Python, JavaScript, PHP, Ruby, Lisp. ::: ### Julia type system Julia type system is *dynamic* (types are unknown until runtime), but types *can* be declared, optionally bringing the advantages of static type systems. This gives users the freedom to choose between an easy and convenient language, or a clearer, faster, and more robust one (or a combination of the two). ## Julia types: a hierarchical tree At the bottom:  **concrete types**. \ Above:     **abstract types** (concepts for collections of concrete types). \ At the top:     the **`Any` type**, encompassing all types. ![from O'Reilly](img/type.png){width="80%"} One common type missing in this diagram is the boolean type. It is a subtype of the integer type, as can be tested with the subtype operator `<:` ::: {#2 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Bool <: Integer ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` true ``` ::: ::: It can also be made obvious by the following: ::: {#4 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} false == 0 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` true ``` ::: ::: ::: {#6 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} true == 1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` true ``` ::: ::: ::: {#8 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} a = true; b = false; 3a + 2b ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 3 ``` ::: ::: ## Optional type declaration Done with `::` ```{.julia} :: ``` :::{.example} Example: ::: ::: {#10 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} 2::Int ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 2 ``` ::: ::: ## Illustration of type safety This works: ::: {#12 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} 2::Int ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 2 ``` ::: ::: This doesn't work: ::: {#14 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} 2.0::Int ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
TypeError: in typeassert, expected Int64, got a value of type Float64
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ ~/parvus/prog/mint/julia/intro_types.qmd:99
``` ::: ::: ::: Type declaration is not yet supported on global variables; this is used in local contexts such as inside a function. :::{.example} Example: ::: ::: {#16 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function floatsum(a, b) (a + b)::Float64 end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` floatsum (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: This works: ::: {#18 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} floatsum(2.3, 1.0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 3.3 ``` ::: ::: This doesn't work: ::: {#20 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} floatsum(2, 4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
TypeError: in typeassert, expected Float64, got a value of type Int64
Stacktrace:
 [1] floatsum(a::Int64, b::Int64)
   @ Main.Notebook ~/parvus/prog/mint/julia/intro_types.qmd:112
 [2] top-level scope
   @ ~/parvus/prog/mint/julia/intro_types.qmd:125
``` ::: ::: ::: ## Information and conversion The `typeof` function gives the type of an object: ::: {#22 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} typeof(2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#24 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} typeof(2.0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#26 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} typeof("Hello, World!") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` String ``` ::: ::: ::: {#28 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} typeof(true) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Bool ``` ::: ::: ::: {#30 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} typeof((2, 4, 1.0, "test")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Tuple{Int64, Int64, Float64, String} ``` ::: ::: Conversion between types is possible in some cases: ::: {#32 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Int(2.0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#34 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} typeof(Int(2.0)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#36 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Char(2.0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` '\x02': ASCII/Unicode U+0002 (category Cc: Other, control) ``` ::: ::: ::: {#38 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} typeof(Char(2.0)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Char ``` ::: ::: ## Stylistic convention The names of types start with a capital letter and camel case is used in multiple-word names.
